stories.headline: US Supreme Court strikes down Trump's global tariffs in major blow to presidential authority
stories.body: The US Supreme Court ruled 6-3 that President Trump's sweeping global tariffs imposed under the International Emergency Economic Powers Act of 1977 were illegal, finding that the power to levy tariffs belongs to Congress, not the executive branch. Chief Justice John Roberts wrote that the framers of the Constitution 'very clearly' gave Congress the taxing power and 'did not vest any part of the taxing power in the Executive Branch.' Trump condemned the ruling as 'deeply disappointing' and called the justices who voted against him 'a disgrace to the nation,' before announcing he would immediately impose a new 10% global baseline tariff under Section 122 of the Trade Act of 1974, which allows presidential tariffs for 150 days. The ruling opens the possibility that the government may need to refund billions in tariff revenue already collected, though the court left that question to lower courts.

stories.headline: Police search Prince Andrew's homes as Epstein investigation deepens
stories.body: British police continued searching the former Royal Lodge residence of Andrew Mountbatten-Windsor on Friday, one day after the 66-year-old was released under investigation following an 11-hour detention on suspicion of misconduct in public office linked to his friendship with convicted sex offender Jeffrey Epstein. The investigation centres on allegations that Andrew shared confidential British government documents with Epstein while serving as the government's special trade representative. King Charles issued a rare personally signed statement insisting 'the law must take its course.' The UK government is now considering introducing legislation to remove Andrew from the royal line of succession, with support from the Liberal Democrats, SNP, and some Labour MPs. Such a move would require an act of Parliament and approval from 14 Commonwealth nations.

stories.headline: Iran calls US military buildup 'unnecessary' as Trump considers limited strikes
stories.body: Iranian Foreign Minister Abbas Araghchi said a diplomatic solution with the United States is 'at our reach' and called the enormous US military buildup in the Middle East, which includes two aircraft carriers and dozens of fighter jets, 'unnecessary and unhelpful.' Hours later, Trump told reporters he is considering limited strikes against Iran to force a deal. The USS Gerald R Ford, the world's largest aircraft carrier, entered the Mediterranean through the Strait of Gibraltar en route to the Gulf region. The US and Iran have held two rounds of talks over the past month, with Trump giving Tehran between 10 and 15 days to reach an agreement, though Araghchi warned that Iranians are 'proud people' who only respond to the 'language of respect.'

stories.headline: Venezuela approves amnesty law for political prisoners amid cautious optimism
stories.body: Venezuela's parliament unanimously approved a historic amnesty law for political prisoners, following the release of more than 400 detainees since January according to human rights group Foro Penal. The releases came after the US-led operation that removed former President Nicolas Maduro from power in January. Among those freed was journalist Ramon Centeno, who spent four years imprisoned over an interview the government disapproved of, though his mother died of a stroke just 13 days after witnessing his release. Critics question whether the releases signal a genuine political opening, noting that many freed prisoners face legal restrictions and fear re-arrest, while analysts describe Venezuela as being at a crossroads where economic openness is clear but political liberalisation remains uncertain.

stories.headline: NASA targets 6 March for historic Artemis II moon mission
stories.body: NASA announced it is targeting 6 March for the launch of Artemis II, which will send four astronauts around the moon for the first time since Apollo 17 in 1972. The decision came after a successful fuel loading test on Thursday resolved dangerous liquid hydrogen leaks that had disrupted an earlier rehearsal. Administrator Jared Isaacman said the team made 'major progress' between the two tests. The four astronauts, three Americans and one Canadian, entered health quarantine on Friday in Houston. The mission will conduct a 10-day trip around the moon without landing, flying approximately 4,700 miles beyond the far side of the moon and surpassing the distance record set by Apollo 13 in 1970.

stories.headline: Supreme Court tariffs ruling reshapes Trump's economic agenda
stories.body: The Supreme Court's 6-3 decision striking down Trump's sweeping tariffs under IEEPA sent shockwaves through Washington, with the president calling it 'deeply disappointing' and announcing an immediate pivot to alternative tariff authorities. Trump said he would sign a new 10% global baseline tariff under Section 122 of the Trade Act of 1974, which permits presidential tariffs for 150 days without congressional approval. Some Republican lawmakers quietly welcomed the ruling, reflecting intraparty anxiety over tariffs that had disrupted supply chains and raised consumer prices. The decision also raises complex questions about refunding billions already collected, which Justice Kavanaugh warned in his dissent could be a 'mess.'

stories.headline: Recovery efforts resume after deadly California avalanche kills eight
stories.body: Crews were hoping to resume recovery operations on Friday for the bodies of eight people killed in a devastating avalanche in California's Sierra Nevada, after days of dangerous weather hampered access to the remote site near Lake Tahoe. Among the victims were a group of six mothers who had bonded over their shared love of the outdoors and were on a backcountry ski trip led by a professional guide service. One person remains missing. An investigation is underway into the circumstances of the avalanche, with questions emerging about whether unstable conditions caused by an unusual snow drought contributed to the disaster.

stories.headline: Israeli settlers kill 19-year-old Palestinian American in West Bank
stories.body: A 19-year-old Palestinian American man, Nasrallah Abu Siyam, was shot and killed by Israeli settlers during clashes in the occupied West Bank village of Mukhmas late Wednesday night, according to the Palestinian Health Ministry and witnesses. His father and mourners gathered for his funeral in the village east of Ramallah on Thursday. The killing comes amid ongoing tensions in the West Bank, where settler violence against Palestinians has escalated significantly during the war in Gaza.

stories.headline: Trump considers limited strike on Iran as nuclear talks continue
stories.body: President Trump told reporters on Friday that he is considering a limited military strike on Iran to force the country into a nuclear deal, escalating rhetoric even as both sides described recent negotiations as positive. The US has continued to amass military assets around Iran, with the USS Gerald R Ford aircraft carrier now transiting toward the Gulf region. Trump had previously given Iran between 10 and 15 days to reach an agreement, after warning of 'something very tough' and 'traumatic' consequences. The statement came hours after Iran's foreign minister said a deal was achievable through diplomacy.

stories.headline: Immigration enforcement controversies mount across the country
stories.body: A federal judge accused the Trump administration of 'terror' against immigrants in a scathing ruling on detention bonds, while a new administration order could lead to the detention of thousands of legal refugees. In Savannah, Georgia, a beloved teacher was mourned after a deadly crash involving a driver being pursued by ICE agents. Meanwhile, police in another city opened an investigation into an ICE arrest after a man suffered severe head injuries during the encounter. The incidents highlight growing tensions around the administration's intensified immigration enforcement campaign.

stories.headline: La Sagrada Familia reaches its maximum height as tower of Jesus is completed
stories.body: Barcelona's Sagrada Familia reached its maximum height of 172.5 metres on Friday morning when workers placed the upper arm of the cross atop the Tower of Jesus, making it the tallest church in the world and the tallest building in Barcelona. The 11-tonne steel and glass piece was winched into position just before noon under clear skies after days of high winds had delayed the operation. Chief architect Jordi Fauli said it was 'a joyful day for all the people who have made it possible.' The four-sided cross measures 17 metres tall and 13.5 metres wide and will eventually be visitable as an observation point. The tower will be formally blessed by Pope Leo XIV on 10 June, the centenary of Antoni Gaudi's death, with the full basilica expected to be completed within a decade.

stories.headline: Vox in turmoil as co-founder Ortega Smith vows to fight expulsion
stories.body: The far-right party Vox is experiencing its deepest internal crisis as co-founder and Madrid city councillor Javier Ortega Smith publicly defied leader Santiago Abascal's attempt to expel him from the party. At an impromptu press conference, Ortega Smith declared he would fight through internal party channels and the courts if necessary, accusing the leadership of 'dirty war' and persecution. Abascal had initiated expulsion proceedings after Ortega Smith refused to step down as the party's spokesperson on Madrid city council. The dispute marks the culmination of months of tensions, with Ortega Smith claiming in a letter that the party leadership has systematically targeted prominent founding members who question the current direction.

stories.headline: Police sexual assault scandal rocks Spain's national police force
stories.body: Spain's national police force is reeling from a sexual assault scandal involving its former director of operations (DAO), the highest-ranking uniformed officer in the 76,700-strong force. An inspector who reported a sexual assault by the DAO bypassed internal protocols and went directly to the courts, a decision that fellow officers say reflects deep distrust in the system. Female officers described the internal reporting mechanisms as ineffective and potentially harmful to victims, with one guardia civil representative advising women against using internal channels due to the month-long process of 'wear and tear' they entail. The DAO resigned almost immediately, though some officers said they would have preferred a dismissal.

stories.headline: Mazon's driver contradicts former Valencia president's account of DANA flood night
stories.body: The driver of former Valencia regional president Carlos Mazon testified on Friday that the emergency Es-Alert warning sounded on their mobile phone while they were still driving through central Valencia toward the emergency coordination centre on the night of the catastrophic DANA floods that killed 230 people in October 2024. His testimony contradicts one of Mazon's multiple accounts of that evening, in which the former president claimed he had been working at the Palau de la Generalitat during the afternoon. The driver said he was called around 7pm to take Mazon to the emergency centre in l'Eliana, and they did not arrive until 8:28pm according to security cameras, well after the emergency alert was issued at 8:11pm.

stories.headline: Father kills 10-year-old son with machete in Tenerife before being shot dead by police
stories.body: A 35-year-old man murdered his 10-year-old son with a 60-centimetre machete and critically injured the boy's mother in the town of Arona, Tenerife, in the early hours of Friday morning. Neighbours alerted the Guardia Civil after hearing screams from the apartment. When officers arrived, they found the child dead with severe head wounds and the 26-year-old mother with grave injuries to her limbs. The man attacked the responding officers with extreme violence, wounding one in the arm, before being fatally shot. The case has been classified as gender-based violence, with Spain's government delegate noting that since records began, 1,352 women, 62 children, and 500 orphans have been victims of such violence in the country.

stories.headline: Sagrada Familia completes Tower of Jesus, becoming world's tallest church
stories.body: The Sagrada Familia completed its Tower of Jesus on Friday morning, reaching 172.5 metres and becoming both the tallest building in Barcelona and the tallest church in the world. The final piece, an 11-tonne steel and glass cross arm, was winched into place at 11am after days of delays due to high winds from Storm Pedro. As Catalan and Vatican flags were raised at the summit, chief architect Jordi Fauli celebrated with visible emotion. The cross will eventually serve as an observation point accessible to visitors starting in 2027. Pope Leo XIV is expected to bless the tower on 10 June, the centenary of Gaudi's death, while the full basilica including the Glory facade is expected to take another decade to complete.

stories.headline: Pisarello wins Barcelona en Comu primary to be mayoral candidate
stories.body: Gerardo Pisarello, currently a Sumar MP in the Spanish Congress and former first deputy mayor under Ada Colau, won the Barcelona en Comu primary election with 68.6% of the vote, defeating writer and broadcaster Bob Pop who received 27%. Pisarello will lead the party's ticket for the 2027 municipal elections alongside councillor Carol Recio in second position. He had the backing of former mayor Ada Colau and minister Ernest Urtasun, while Bob Pop had positioned himself as an alternative to the party establishment with his campaign slogan 'Why not?'

stories.headline: Rodalies commuter rail still in crisis one month after deadly Gelida accident
stories.body: One month after a fatal train crash at Gelida that killed a trainee driver and injured 37 people, Barcelona's Rodalies commuter rail network remains far from normal. While Renfe says 80% of the network is now operational, 224 speed restrictions are in force across the system, roughly one every six kilometres, causing significant delays. The R3 line remains entirely replaced by buses, and portions of the R4 line around the crash site still require bus substitution. This week, 42 new critical points were identified, adding more speed restrictions starting Monday. Many commuters have abandoned the service entirely, with daily users enduring much longer journey times and persistent lack of information.

stories.headline: Nearly 400 infractions found in businesses around Park Guell
stories.body: A multi-agency inspection of 27 businesses around Barcelona's Park Guell uncovered 396 infractions, leading to five premises being shut down. Four were closed due to electrical supply and installation issues, while one was sealed for public health reasons related to pest infestations. The majority of infractions related to mismatches between the businesses' actual activities and their licences, with many souvenir shops operating without proper permits or combining activities they were not authorised to conduct. Food establishments showed problems with food storage, hygiene, and expired products. Deputy mayor Laia Bonet said the operation helps 'put order in a reality we cannot tolerate anywhere, but especially not in neighbourhoods with tourist pressure like the area around Park Guell.'

stories.headline: Housing speculation law sparks debate as employers' group calls it 'philocommunist'
stories.body: The agreement between the Catalan government and the Comuns party to restrict speculative property purchases in Catalunya has drawn sharp criticism from the employers' association Foment del Treball, which branded it 'philocommunist.' The deal, aimed at curbing housing speculation, has also raised concerns in the real estate sector that rental supply could shrink further. Meanwhile, tenants' unions and property owners have both expressed dissatisfaction with the measures, with neither side convinced the agreement will effectively address Barcelona's acute housing crisis. Separately, concerns emerged that the regulations could inadvertently affect legitimate building rehabilitations and renovations.
